a b s t r a c t
The ability to process metallic samples at the sub-micrometer scale raised the strength limits of pure metals to the Giga Pascal (GPa) range. Here, we fabricated Mo nanoparticles with a giant compressive strength surpassing the previous strength records of metallic materials. Round and faceted particles were produced by manipulating the annealing atmosphere during two-stage solid-state dewetting of Mo thin films deposited on sapphire. The round particle underwent a huge elastic deformation before yielding abruptly. Using finite element analysis, we found that the resolved shear stress on a {112} 〈 110 〉 slip system beneath the punch reaches an enormous value of 20 ±1 GPa at yield, regardless of particle size. The faceted nanoparticles, contrarily, followed a “smaller is stronger” rule, with uniaxial compressive strength of up to 46 GPa for the smallest nanoparticles. Molecular dynamics simulations indicated that the size effect diminishes with increasing roundness of the particle edges. This work demonstrates how shape and size of particles can be manipulated to achieve giant strength.

1. Introduction
It is now well-established that plastic deformation of crystals of sub-micrometer dimensions proceeds very different from the plastic deformation of bulk crystalline materials [1] . The main reasons behind this change of mechanical behavior with decreasing sample size is an extreme scarcity of dislocation sources at such small scales, and abundance of free surfaces to which the dislocations can escape [ 2 , 3 ]. The term “dislocations starvation” was coined to describe the plastic deformation controlled by nucleation of new dislocations, rather than by the motion of pre-existing dislocations and activity of the internal dislocation sources [4] . The nucleation of new dislocations in structurally perfect single crystal requires much higher stresses than those needed for the activation of pre-existing dislocation sources. This is the reason why an ultrahigh strength was observed in pristine single crystalline samples of a number of different inorganic materials, such as metals [ 3 , 5 , 6 ], semiconductors [7] , and ceramics [8] (see also Ref. [9] and references therein). These new ultra-strong materials (such as nanoparticles and nanowhiskers) can find a wide range of applications

3.4. MD simulations of the particles compression
It was previously shown that the size effect in strength of faceted nanoparticles can be captured in MD simulations [ 3 , 15 , 40 ], while FEA can neither capture nor predict the size dependence only by calculating the maximum RSS. For a better understanding of the atomistic mechanisms behind the high levels of strength achieved in our experiments, and of the effect of size on strength of the faceted particles, we have performed MD simulations of compression of the particles ranging from 10 nm to 65 nm in height with different roundnesses at the edges (see Section 2.3 for details). A roundness parameter χ , which ranges from 0 (fully rounded) to 1 (perfectly faceted), is defined according to Eq. (1) and the simulations are performed for values of χ between 0.4 to 1. An example for two different shapes is given in Fig. 7 (a). Lower values of χ are impractical in MD simulations because of the problems associated with the stepped character of the surface of nearly-spherical particles. From the true stress curve, we obtain the stress at the first load drop, which we associate with plastic yielding of the particle. The resulting size dependencies of compressive strengths for particles with different roundnesses are summarized in Fig. 7 (b). All simulated particles exhibited a pronounced size effect. Similarly to the experiments, the dependence of compressive plastic yield strength on the size obeys a powerlaw. We find that the size effect is more pronounced for the more faceted particles ( χ > 0.7), and as the particle becomes rounded ( χ ≤ 0.7) the size effect exponent reaches a saturation.
The MD simulations reproduce a power-law size dependence of the yield strength; however, the corresponding size exponent is different from the one obtained in the experiments. Moreover, contrary to the experimental observations, the size effect in MD simulations does not vanish for highly rounded particles. This discrepancy highlights the differences between the simulations and the experiments. In previous studies, it was shown that in some cases the strength of crystalline particles is size-dependent [ 3 , 6 , 15 , 16 ], while in some cases it is not [13] . Based on these studies, the sizeeffect was attributed to the stress concentration at the top vertices of the faceted particles, where dislocations are nucleated at the onset of plasticity. In the range χ > 0.7, in which faceting is pronounced, the larger roundness (i.e. smaller values of parameter χ ) manifests itself in a less sensitive size effect, as can be seen in the exponents in Fig. 7 (c). Theoretically, we would expect for this trend to continue as we round the edges, and for the size effect to vanish for fully round particles. However, due to the discreteness of the atomic structure, when large roundness is applied ( χ ≤ 0.7), the atomic surface steps around and beneath the top facet become predominant. Now, nucleation occurs heterogeneously at these atomic steps serving as local stress concentrators for nucleation (see Fig. 7 (d)). Since the atomic steps exhibit constant, size- and shape-independent local morphology for all round particles with χ ≤ 0.7, the stress concentration at the step becomes shape independent and the value of the size effect exponent reaches a lower-bound value. In neither case a homogenous dislocation nucleation (as in Ref. [22] ) was observed.

ith increasing roundness. We compare particles of the same size
ut with different roundness levels at the onset of plasticity. One an see in Fig. 7 (e) that two particles with different roundness exibit nearly equal stress levels at the center of the top facet and t its edge (near the first surface step), where the first dislocaions nucleate at the onset of plasticity. The scaling relationship between compressive stresses at a catastrophic failure and diameter of faceted Mo particles clearly shows a power-law dependence with the exponent n ~ 1.0 as can be seen in Fig. 6 (c). This value is close to the size-effect exponents determined in the experimental compression tests of Au [3] and Ni [6] nanoparticles, and is significantly higher than the size-effect exponents reported in previous studies of the micropillars of refractory BCC metals [ 61 , 69 ]. This highlights the main differences between the mechanical behavior of nanoparticles and of micropillars. This difference is related to the different deformation mechanisms in each case. In pillars, sources from existing dislocations play the major role in the deformation. Screw dislocations play a much more prominent role in the deformation of BCC pillars than their edge counterparts. Unlike the edge dislocations which glide along the well-defined crystallographic planes, the motion of screw dislocations is not confined to any particular set of crystallographic planes. Further, due to the lack of closest-packed atomic planes in the BCC lattice, the screw dislocation cores are non-planar, so that their motion is driven by both glide and non-glide shear stress components of the stress tensor. Also, the mobility of screw dislocations is much lower than that of their edge counterparts due to higher Peierls barrier for screw dislocation in BCC metals [70] . Therefore, the single dislocation becomes the source of new dislocations, leaves behind dislocation debris and further interacts with other dislocation segments, forming Frank-Read sources. This self-multiplication leads to the formation of entangled dislocation structures within the sample and concomitant strain hardening. These differences in deformation mechanisms were identified as a main reason for the significantly lower deformation size-effect exponent determined during compression tests of FIB-machined Mo, Ta and W nanopillars (0.43), as compared to Au pillars (1.0) [ 69 , 71 ]. The similarity of the size effect exponents for the faceted Mo particles and their FCC counterparts indicates that the underlying plasticity mechanisms of nanoparticles are different from those of FIB-machined nanopillars. Indeed, experimental and computation studies of micro-compression of defect-free particles have shown that the onset of plastic deformation is controlled by the dislocation nucleation [ 3 , 6 ]. The models revealed that, depending on their shape, the strength of faceted defect-free metal particles is determined by the modalities of dislocation nucleation in the stress gradient, rather than by their atomic structure (FCC or BCC). The MD simulations performed in the present work captured qualitatively the size effect, but the strength level of the small particles was higher, and the size effect exponent was smaller than determined in the experiment. A similar difference in the exponents was observed in Ni particles [6] . The reason for this difference in the exponents may be an occasional presence of dislocation sources and other defects in the largest studied particles. It is well-known that the probability of finding a defect in the particle obtained by the dewetting technique increases with increasing particle size [72] . Recently it was proposed that when dislocations and their sources are introduced in the metal particles, their compression behavior becomes similar to that of FIB-machined pillars, exhibiting a size-effect which is controlled by the distribution of pinning points and length of dislocation sources [73] . Thus, while the behavior of small particles should be consistent with the results of our MD simulations, large particles containing random defects may exhibit a considerable drop in their strength. In this case, the overall size effect exponent determined for the particles of all sizes studied experimentally should be larger than that determined in MD simulations. It is interesting that the occasional presence of defects discussed above did not affect the strength (maximum RSS or MCP) of round particles. This is probably because the maximum stress in compressed round particle is achieved in a single point beneath the indenter, while in the faceted particle the stress concentration is observed at six corners of the top (011) facet. . Conclusions
From the results of the present study, the following conclusions
an be drawn:
1 We developed a two-stage solid state dewetting process to fab-
ricate Mo micro- and nanoparticles on a sapphire substrate with the self-similar shapes approaching the equilibrium crystal shape of Mo. The single-crystalline Mo particles formed from a thin Mo film after the first dewetting treatment exhibited low aspect ratios and highly non-equilibrium shapes. The sample was scratched with a sharp piece of sapphire, resulting in formation of agglomerates of deformed particles. These agglomerates sintered into fully dense, equilibrated particles after the second annealing. 2 We demonstrated that the shape of the Mo particles formed
after the second annealing can be manipulated by varying the oxygen partial pressure in the annealing ambient. Round particles were formed when the oxygen partial pressure was low (10 −14 atm), whereas highly faceted particles emerged after annealing under higher oxygen partial pressure (10 −12 atm). 3 Both round and faceted particles were tested in compression
and exhibited a deformation behavior that is typical of the plasticity controlled by dislocation nucleation: reversible elastic deformation up to very large strains of several percent, followed by a catastrophic plastic collapse. The faceted particles exhibited a strong size effect in compression, with the smallest particle (with an upper facet of 110 nm in diameter) reaching the giant uniaxial compression strength of 46 GPa. We employed the FEA calculations to determine the maximum resolved shear stress in the round particles at the onset of plastic yielding from the experimentally measured load-displacement curves. The obtained value (20 ±1 GPa) was size-independent, and consistent with the critical resolved shear stress of the faceted particles. The achieved absolute strength values were firmly within the range of the theoretical strength of Mo. 4 We performed the molecular dynamic simulations of compres-
sion tests of Mo particles with varying degree of roundness. We observed the size effect in compression strength, with a size effect exponent decreasing with increasing roundness of the particles (in qualitative agreement with the experimental data). Also, the absolute value of the particle strength increased with increasing particle roundness. This was attributed to the nearly constant amplitude and width of the stress peak near the edge of the top facet (where the first dislocation nucleation event occurs), resulting in higher average stress in the case of more rounded particles exhibiting smaller top facet.
The results of this work confirm the assumption that the lastic deformation of metallic nanostructure is strongly shapeependent, and can be utilized for the design of ultra-strong
etallic components of sub-micrometer dimensions.

metadata.abstractText: The ability to process metallic samples at the sub-micrometer scale raised the strength limits of pure metals to the Giga Pascal (GPa) range. Here, we fabricated Mo nanoparticles with a giant compressive strength surpassing the previous strength records of metallic materials. Round and faceted particles were produced by manipulating the annealing atmosphere during two-stage solid-state dewetting of Mo thin films deposited on sapphire. The round particle underwent a huge elastic deformation before yielding abruptly. Using finite element analysis, we found that the resolved shear stress on a {112} 〈 110 〉 slip system beneath the punch reaches an enormous value of 20 ±1 GPa at yield, regardless of particle size. The faceted nanoparticles, contrarily, followed a “smaller is stronger” rule, with uniaxial compressive strength of up to 46 GPa for the smallest nanoparticles. Molecular dynamics simulations indicated that the size effect diminishes with increasing roundness of the particle edges. This work demonstrates how shape and size of particles can be manipulated to achieve giant strength. © 2020 Acta Materialia Inc. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
